pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 571, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 710, 91]]<|/det|>
Which list places units of length in increasing order of magnitude (size)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 134, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 101, 285, 119]]<|/det|>
cm \(\rightarrow\) mm \(\rightarrow\) m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 146]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 127, 285, 146]]<|/det|>
mm \(\rightarrow\) cm \(\rightarrow\) m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 155, 133, 173]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 154, 285, 173]]<|/det|>
mm \(\rightarrow\) m \(\rightarrow\) cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 182, 133, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 181, 285, 200]]<|/det|>
m \(\rightarrow\) mm \(\rightarrow\) cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 226, 97, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 680, 245]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 721, 536, 740]]<|/det|>
\[W = mg\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 134, 769]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 750, 455, 769]]<|/det|>
$g$ is a force, $m$ and $W$ are not forces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 133, 796]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 777, 455, 796]]<|/det|>
$m$ is a force, $g$ and $W$ are not forces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 133, 823]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 804, 455, 823]]<|/det|>
$W$ is a force, $g$ and $m$ are not forces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 831, 133, 850]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 831, 413, 850]]<|/det|>
None of \(g\), \(m\) and \(W\) are forces.

frictional force needed to pull the box/Ndistance moved across the floor/m
A54
B102
C152
D204
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 515, 96, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 571, 533]]<|/det|> Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 546, 576, 564]]<|/det|> In which order is the energy transferred in this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 134, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 658, 593]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 134, 621]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 603, 658, 621]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 631, 134, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 631, 658, 648]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 658, 134, 676]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 658, 658, 675]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 701, 96, 719]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 701, 227, 719]]<|/det|> A stone falls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 435, 749]]<|/det|> Which row gives the energy changes? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 526, 904]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energykinetic energy
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

The liquid is not boiling. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 646, 120]]<|/det|> Which statement about the liquid is correct at an instant in time? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 626, 149]]<|/det|> Any molecule can escape, and from any part of the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 646, 175]]<|/det|> Any molecule can escape, but only from the liquid's surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 134, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 181, 836, 200]]<|/det|> Only molecules with enough energy can escape, and only from the liquid's surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 207, 804, 226]]<|/det|> Only molecules with enough energy can escape, but from any part of the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 106, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 920, 288]]<|/det|> The temperature of the gas in a sealed container of constant volume decreases from \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(12^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 300, 297, 317]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 551, 475]]<|/det|>
pressure of the gas in the containeraverage speed of the molecules of gas
Adecreasesdecreases
Bstays the sameincreases
Cincreasesstays the same
Dstays the samedecreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 833, 89]]<|/det|> A teacher makes the statement, 'Object P has a higher thermal capacity than object Q.' <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 391, 119]]<|/det|> What does this statement mean? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 564, 147]]<|/det|> Object P has a higher melting point than object Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 134, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 556, 174]]<|/det|> Object P has a lower melting point than object Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 129, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 920, 216]]<|/det|> The increase in temperature of object P is greater than that of object Q for the same increase in internal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 134, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|> The increase in temperature of object P is smaller than that of object Q for the same increase in internal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 284, 106, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 520, 301]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a pan used for cooking food. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[314, 310, 680, 459]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 473, 845, 491]]<|/det|> Which row is correct for the materials used to make the base and the handle of the pan? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 502, 670, 631]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 134, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 518, 201, 537]]<|/det|> 250V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 518, 298, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 518, 371, 537]]<|/det|> 200V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 518, 467, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 518, 515, 537]]<|/det|> 5A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 518, 635, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 518, 683, 537]]<|/det|> 3A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 564, 107, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 853, 583]]<|/det|> A very important experiment improved scientists' understanding of the structure of matter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 655, 613]]<|/det|> The experiment involved \(\alpha\) -particles being fired at a thin, gold foil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 262, 643]]<|/det|> What happened? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 134, 673]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 655, 687, 673]]<|/det|> All the \(\alpha\) -particles were absorbed by the nuclei of the gold atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 131, 701]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 682, 591, 701]]<|/det|> All the \(\alpha\) -particles were unaffected by the gold atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 710, 131, 728]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 710, 858, 728]]<|/det|> Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were attracted by the neutrons in the nuclei of the gold atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 737, 131, 756]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 737, 843, 756]]<|/det|> Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were repelled by the protons in the nuclei of the gold atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 780, 107, 798]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 546, 798]]<|/det|> A sample contains \(0.0016 \text{g}\) of a radioactive isotope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 810, 798, 828]]<|/det|> After 4.0 hours the mass of the radioactive isotope in the sample falls to \(0.00080 \text{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 840, 500, 858]]<|/det|> What is the half-life of the radioactive isotope? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 868, 133, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 868, 235, 887]]<|/det|> 2.0 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 868, 400, 887]]<|/det|> B 4.0 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 868, 470, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 868, 567, 887]]<|/det|> 8.0 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 868, 636, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 868, 730, 887]]<|/det|> 16 hours
